para: ROI stands for Region of Interest. ROI's designate a volume on the object over which statistics should be calculated.

sect2.title: ROI Types
sect2.para: The following ROI types are currently supported.

sect3.title: Ellipsoid
sect3.para: An ellipsoid is similar to a sphere, but with a radius specified for each direction [x,y,z]. In the case of x=y=z, the ellipsoid is a sphere.

sect3.title: Elliptic Cylinder
sect3.para: An elliptic cylinder is similar to a regular cylinder, except it has an ellipse as it's base instead of a circle.

sect3.title: Box
sect3.para: Exactly what it says, a 3D box.

sect3.title: Isocontours
sect3.para: Isocontour ROI's are regions selected from the data set such that the edge values of the ROI are always the same value. There are two types, 2D and 3D isocontours.

sect4.title: 2D Isocontour
sect4.para: A 2D isocontour is derived by considering a value on one of the displayed 2D slices. The depth of a 2D isocontour is specified initially by the depth of the viewed slices.

sect4.title: 3D Isocontour
sect4.para: A 3D isocontour is derived by considering a value on the current frame of the active data set.

sect2.title: Drawing ROI's
sect2.para: To draw an ROI, first select the ROI desired under the "add ROI:" pull down menu. Amide will request a name for this ROI and add it to the study item list, but no ROI will be drawn. The next mouse input on the displayed views will be used to draw the new ROI. For ellipsoid, elliptic cylinder, and box ROI's, The x and y dimensions of the ROI are controlled by the size of the drawing. The z dimension ("depth") of the newly drawn ROI is determined by the current image thickness. For isocontour's, the value of the data set at the clicked upon location will be used to derive the isocontour.

sect2.title: Manipulating ROI's
sect2.para:
After an ROI is drawn, it can be further manipulated to adjust it's size, placement, and orientation. You can directly manipulate the ROI by clicking on it in any of the viewing windows. Mouse button 1 is used to shift ROIs. Mouse button 2 is used to rotate ellipsoid, elliptic cylinder, and box ROIs, and for erasing points from isocontour ROI's. Mouse button 3 is used for zooming ellipsoid, elliptic cylinder and box ROI, and is used for redefining the isocontour value for isocontour ROI's.
You can also edit the ROI size/placement/orientation/name etc. by clicking on mouse button 3 while over the ROI's name in the study item list. This brings up the edit ROI dialog, which allows keyboard entry of the ROI's parameters.

sect2.title: Calculating Statistics over ROI's
sect2.para: Statistics on an ROI can be calculated via the analysis menu. Choosing "All" will calculate all the ROI's on the currently selected images. Choosing "Selected" will calculate the selected ROI's on the currently selected images.

sect3.title: Variance/Std. Dev./Std. Err. Fallacies
sect3.para: A common fallacy is to use the calculated variance (or standard deviation, or standard error) of an ROI as an experiment's variance. The variance of an experiment can only truly be measured by taking multiple samples (i.e. performing multiple scans) and calculating the variance between these different samples. The variance that AMIDE calculates is only a measure of the noise within an ROI in the given data set.

sect3.title: Changing Calculated Volume
sect3.para: AMIDE calculates ROI's by translating the ROI's dimensions into the data set's coordinate space. It then computes statistics for all the data set voxels that are in the ROI. For voxels that lie on the edge of the ROI, AMIDE will subdivide the voxel into a finite number of subvoxels, and calculate over the subvoxels. This approach yields correct statistics, but it is important to realize that the computed ROI is a discrete representation of the specified analytical ROI. So while the true volume of an ellipse is pi*r1*r2*r3, the computed volume of the ellipse in AMIDE will depend on the number of voxels and subvoxels that were determined to line within the ellipse, which in turn can depend on the orientation of the ROI. Since the computed volume given by AMIDE represents the volume in the data set that was used for the ROI calculation, you will want to use that value (not the real ellipse value).
